title: The Works of Robert Louis Stevenson - Swanston Edition, Vol. 9
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Thus hewas for me a mirror of things perished; it was only in his memory that Icould see the huge shock of flames of the May beacon stream to leeward,and the watchers, as they fed the fire, lay hold unscorched of thewindward bars of the furnace; it was only thus that I could see mygrandfather driving swiftly in a gig along the seaboard road fromPittenweem to Crail, and for all his business hurry, drawing up to speakgood-humouredly with those he met.

title: Royal Edinburgh; Her Saints, Kings, Prophets and Poets
author: Oliphant, Mrs. (Margaret)
snippet: Major gives the same high character of the great Bishop,declaring that there were but two things in him which did not meritapproval--the fact that he held a priory (but only one, that ofPittenweem) _in commendam_, "and the sumptuositie of his sepulchre."

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: St. Andrews unites with Cupar, Anstruther, Pittenweem, Crail, and Kilrenny, in returning a member to Parliament.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: A mile from Pittenweem  is Anstruther (population, 152G), commemorated iu the popular song of " Maggie Lauder." " Anster Fair," also, has been made the subject  of an amusing poem by Mr. Tennant, late Professor of Oriental Languages in the University of St. Andrews.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Pittenweem contains the house in which Wilson and Robertson committed the robbery upon the collector of excise, which led to the famous Porteous Mob.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: A mile to the east is the ancient royal burgh of Pittenweem.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Thus he was for me a mirror of things perished; it was only in his memory that I could see the huge shock of flames of the May beacon stream to leeward, and the watchers, as they fed the fire, lay hold unscorched of the windward bars of the furnace; it was only thus that I could see my grandfather driving swiftly in a gig along the seaboard road from Pittenweem to Crail, and for all his business hurry, drawing up to speak good-humouredly with those he met.

title: The novels and tales of Robert Louis Stevenson.
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: Though the season was summer, the SL Regulus of Pittenweem did not cross the German Ocean without peril ; for one night, and during the following day, there blew a tempest from the south-cast, which drove her so far from her course, that the tacking to and fro of a whole week were required ere she could regain the lost distance ; for the reader must bear in mind that the high-pooped, high prowed, and low-waisted craft of those days, were very different from the screw-propellers and iron clippers of the present age ; and heavily they lumbered  along, with Dutch lee-boards, basketed tops, their spritsail-yards, jack-staffs, and other ponderous hamper.

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: J^egulus, a caravel belonging to the monks of St. Mary, at Pittenweem, who were great traders and shipowners in those days.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: By these feints Mar was enabled to get the troops, designed to form the expedition, moved in secrecy down to Pittenweem, the Ely, Crail, and other small portsso numerous on that coast.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Upon a choice of difficulties, however, thecrossing of the Frith from Pittenweem, Crail, and other towns situated to theeastward on the Fife coast, was determined on.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: But Robertson representing the noisethey heard as a dispute or fray betwixt the collector and thepeople of the house, the worthy citizens of Pittenweem feltthemselves no way called on to interfere in behalf of the obnoxious revenue officer; so satisfying themselves with thisvery superficial account of the matter, like the Levite in thaparable, they passed on the opposite side of the way.
